newsArray.title: India vs New Zealand LIVE score 2nd T20I: Another wash out on the cards in Mount Maunganui
creator: Somya Kapoor
newsArray.description: India vs New Zealand LIVE score 2nd T20I: Another wash out on the cards in Mount Maunganui
newsArray.content: 10:54 (IST)The rain looks to have passed and the covers are coming off at @BayOvalOfficial üëç Excited for a sold out crowd tonight! #NZvIND #CricketNation pic.twitter.com/VPuCG33obv‚Äî BLACKCAPS (@BLACKCAPS) November 20, 202210:49 (IST)India vs New Zealand¬† First things first. There is a high possibility of rain in Mount Maunganui which can eventually result in a curtailed game or a wash out¬†10:39 (IST)Hello and welcome to the LIVE COVERAGE of the second T20I between India and New ZealandPREVIEW: The action now moves to Mount Maunganui where India and New Zealand will lock horns in the second T20I. The first clash of the three-match series was washed away due to rain in Wellington while the second game is also under dark clouds as there is a possibility of rain today as well.India are touring New Zealand for three T20Is and as many ODIs. While the T20I side is being led by Hardik Pandya in absence of the senior players, Shikhar Dhawan will be the captain of the ODI team.SQUADS:India: Shubman Gill, Ishan Kishan, Sanju Samson, Suryakumar Yadav, Hardik Pandya(c), Rishabh Pant(w), Deepak Hooda, Bhuvneshwar Kumar, Yuzvendra Chahal, Arshdeep Singh, Umran Malik, Washington Sundar, Mohammed Siraj, Shreyas Iyer, Kuldeep Yadav, Harshal PatelNew Zealand: Finn Allen, Devon Conway(w), Kane Williamson(c), Glenn Phillips, Daryl Mitchell, James Neesham, Mitchell Santner, Tim Southee, Adam Milne, Lockie Ferguson, Blair Tickner, Michael Bracewell, Ish SodhiRead all the Latest News, Trending News, Cricket News, Bollywood News, India News and Entertainment News here. newsArray.title: Buzz: Matty Johns cops Mundine whacks for a good cause
newsArray.description: Matty Johns hasn‚Äôt had a decent punch-up since he infamously flattened brother Joey outside a Newcastle pub back in the 90‚Äôs.
newsArray.content: On Saturday Matty made his comeback ‚Äì stepping into the ring against his long-time mate Anthony Mundine for the charity launch of Choc‚Äôs new foundation that is all about mental health.You can check out the video online.‚ÄúI turned up to the launch dressed to go out to lunch with Trish,‚Äù Johns said.‚ÄúChoc says jump in the ring bra.‚ÄúAll the crowd were urging me to do it so I had to. I even jumped in with my dress shoes on.‚ÄúChoc whispered to me: ‚ÄòHow hard do you wanna go bra.‚Äô‚ÄúI said one out of 10 thanks Choc and he says: ‚Äòhow about six.‚Äô‚ÄúHe whacked me a few times but it was all good fun for a great cause.‚ÄùJohns and controversial brain surgeon Dr Charlie Teo were among the celebrity guests.‚ÄúChoc is a great man,‚Äù Johns said, ‚ÄúI always said history would judge him well.‚ÄúI love that he looks after his people and does a lot of great charity work.‚Äù No-show cricketers ripping off fans and FoxNo wonder cricket crowds for the Australia v England one-dayers have been so ordinary.Imagine paying money for a seat at the SCG on Saturday.You arrive at the ground to find Australian captain and local hero Pat Cummins has been rested.Seriously, anyone would think these guys are playing a contact sport.The Australian team was bounced out of the T20 World Cup early and hardly needed a rest.The exciting all-rounder Cameron Green didn‚Äôt play either- he was sent home to WA to start preparing for the Test match series.Imagine if it was a rock concert. That you‚Äôd paid good money for a ticket but the lead singer and another key member of the band didn‚Äôt turn up.Once a ticket to an Australia v England cricket game was gold but this one-day cricket series is a complete rip-off.Imagine how the broadcasters feel.Foxtel is paying squillions for the exclusive rights to one-day cricket.Their subscribers are being ripped off as much as those paying at the turnstiles. It‚Äôs wrong.Highlights and LowlightsHIGHLIGHTThe Jillaroos‚Äô magnificent 54-4 victory over the Kiwis in the World Cup final, showing once again the extraordinary growth in speed, skill and strength of the women‚Äôs game in Australia. LOWLIGHTA last-minute alcohol ban at stadiums in Qatar for the soccer World Cup, infuriating official FIFA sponsor Budweiser and fans from all over the world who love a beer at the footy. SPOTTEDThere was one bonus for Kiwi coach Michael Maguire getting knocked out of the World Cup in the semi-final loss to Australia. It allowed Madge to be at E.S Marks Field in Kensington on Friday evening to watch his kids at Little Athletics. SPOTTEDIllawarra rugby league royalty at Kembla Grange on Saturday for the Gong meeting. Garry Jack and Rod Wishart are both still looking fit enough to strap on the boots again.SPOTTEDKiwi five-eighth Kieran Foran - still in the heart of Sea Eagles territory - Christmas shopping with his partner and kids at Warringah Mall on Saturday.SHOOSHWhich Wests Tigers star is furious about the treatment of Jackson Hastings and has asked his manager to investigate options at other clubs. BIG BREKKYCatch you on the Big Sports Breakfasts with Laurie Daley, Michael Clarke and Gerard Middleton to discuss all the issues from the World Cup final.

newsArray.title: India vs New Zealand 2nd T20I weather update: Rain threat looms large over Bay Oval, another washout on cards
creator: FirstCricket Staff
newsArray.description: India vs New Zealand 2nd T20I weather update: Rain threat looms large over Bay Oval, another washout on cards
newsArray.content: Team India, who are seeking some game time, are likely to face a tough challenge from New Zealand when both sides lock horns in the second T20I of the three-match series on Sunday at the Bay Oval in Mount Maunganui.Notably, the series opener in Wellington was washed out due to continuous rain and the Indian players must be itching to get onto the park which, inarguably, has the most scenic backdrop. However, the bad news for the fans and the players is that the forecast for the second match doesn‚Äôt look promising either.The latest weather report suggests dark clouds over Bay Oval during the game time. There is a 90% chance of rain during the match, while the temperature on Sunday will hover in the range of 15-18 degrees Celsius with 80-85% humidity.But, there is still a slight chance of India vs New Zealand second T20I going ahead as the probability of precipitation is expected decrease in the evening.The match will begin at 7:30 PM local time (12 PM IST).Interestingly, the team batting first has won all T20I matches at the Bay Oval but with rain likely to reduce the overs, the toss-winning captain will most likely opt to bowl first.Squads:India: Shubman Gill, Ishan Kishan, Sanju Samson, Suryakumar Yadav, Hardik Pandya(c), Rishabh Pant(w), Deepak Hooda, Bhuvneshwar Kumar, Yuzvendra Chahal, Arshdeep Singh, Umran Malik, Washington Sundar, Mohammed Siraj, Shreyas Iyer, Kuldeep Yadav, Harshal PatelNew Zealand: Finn Allen, Devon Conway(w), Kane Williamson(c), Glenn Phillips, Daryl Mitchell, James Neesham, Mitchell Santner, Tim Southee, Adam Milne, Lockie Ferguson, Blair Tickner, Michael Bracewell, Ish Sodhi.Read all the Latest News, Trending News, Cricket News, Bollywood News, India News and Entertainment News here. Follow us on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.

newsArray.title: Does axed Starc hold $10m IPL regrets?
newsArray.description: Mitchell Starc has revealed he had a no-nonsense chat with George Bailey about his shock World Cup axing, declaring he has no regrets over his $10 million IPL sacrifice.
newsArray.content: The left-arm destroyer‚Äôs first-over demolition of England‚Äôs top order at the SCG on Saturday night snapshotted the error Australia might have made in not playing Starc for the final World Cup match against Afghanistan, where rapid-fire wickets could have opened up a semi-final opportunity.Starc refused to divulge details of his heart-to-heart with the National Selector, other than to confirm he shared some ‚Äústrong opinions‚Äù on his shock axing.‚ÄúGeorge and I have spoken and that is where it will stay,‚Äù said Starc after routing England with a four-wicket masterclass.‚ÄúI had strong opinions on it and had a conversation, and that‚Äôs where it is.‚ÄùDespite his extraordinary record taking first over wickets particularly in white ball cricket, Starc was taken away from the new ball in the World Cup for most matches, but is adamant he can still spearhead Australia at the next World Cup in the USA in 2024.‚ÄúYeah, why not? I don‚Äôt have to worry about T20s for another nine months,‚Äù said Starc.‚ÄúI spoke to George at length. It was a good conversation. Many different things were floated there.‚ÄúI still have ambitions to play T20 cricket for Australia but it is a long time to the next one and a lot of water to go under the bridge. So we will face that when we get to that.‚ÄùAfter his World Cup dumping, it was suggested that Starc had sabotaged his Twenty20 form by continually snubbing the Indian Premier League for the past seven years.Starc says maybe so, but refuses to apologise for making Test cricket his No.1 driving force.‚ÄúIt may have, but if I‚Äôd gone in there and having no break and playing 12 months of the year, what does that affect? Does that affect my body? Do I break down? Does it affect my red-ball cricket?,‚Äù said Starc.‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt just sit there and go, ‚Äòhe should go to the IPL because he‚Äôd be a better T20 bowler.‚Äô‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the downside of that? Do I give away a format of the game because I‚Äôm playing 12 months of the year?‚ÄúIn my mind I don‚Äôt regret any of those decisions not to go.‚ÄùMitch Starc PollFor that reason there is a feeling Australian cricket has grossly underappreciated the quiet sacrifices Starc has made for his country, electing to preserve his body and mind for Test cricket rather than make easy money in the IPL.Despite being a lightning rod for criticism over the years for his performances in Test cricket, the truth is Starc has been Australia‚Äôs best Test bowler for the past 18 months and in the upcoming Test series against the West Indies he is on track to become the fastest Australian to 300 wickets after Dennis Lillee, Glenn McGrath, Warne and Mitchell Johnson.It‚Äôs understood Starc was ranked lower than Josh Hazlewood on this year‚Äôs Cricket Australia contract list, despite the fact he powered last summer‚Äôs Ashes triumph and was the preferred second quick alongside Pat Cummins in Pakistan and Sri Lanka.Australia currently has a headache on its hands with gun all-rounder Cameron Green intending to go to his first IPL in the midst of one of the most packed calendars Australian cricket has seen.Green pulled up sore from the first ODI against England and has returned to Perth to prepare for the first Test ‚Äì another reminder of the delicate management needed to ensure the prodigy does not burn out.Starc refused to comment on whether his IPL sacrifices had been underappreciated, but confirmed the decision to knock back at least one-two million dollars a year for the past seven years was made chiefly with Australian Test cricket as his No.1 priority.‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not for me to say. It‚Äôs my decision. I feel like particularly last year, if I take my Test cricket from the past 12-18 months and how that‚Äôs benefited from the break that I‚Äôve had through IPL periods, that‚Äôs paid for itself I guess,‚Äù said Starc.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs always been my decision and that is part of the reason that I do it, to give myself that break physically and mentally. And the other side of it is to see and spend time with my wife (Australian women‚Äôs captain Alyssa Healy) away from cricket.‚ÄùStarc said even without playing IPL it would be impossible for him to continue playing all three formats for Australia for the long-term.

newsArray.title: Ashwin defends Dravid‚Äôs absence from New Zealand tour; here‚Äôs what he said
creator: Post News Network
newsArray.description: New Delhi: Veteran India off-spinner R Ashwin has defended India head coach Rahul Dravid‚Äôs absence from the New Zealand tour, saying the support staff ‚Äúneeded a break‚Äù after putting in extensive work in preparation for the T20 World Cup. Days after Dravid‚Äôs predecessor Ravi Shastri had questioned why an India coach would need a break [‚Ä¶]
newsArray.content: Ashwin defends Dravid‚Äôs absence from New Zealand tour; here‚Äôs what he said PTI Updated: November 20th, 2022, 09:15 IST in Sports 0 Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share on WhatsApp Share on Linkedin New Delhi: Veteran India off-spinner R Ashwin has defended India head coach Rahul Dravid‚Äôs absence from the New Zealand tour, saying the support staff ‚Äúneeded a break‚Äù after putting in extensive work in preparation for the T20 World Cup. Days after Dravid‚Äôs predecessor Ravi Shastri had questioned why an India coach would need a break when they get ‚Äútwo-three months‚Äù off during the IPL, Ashwin said that the coaching staff was physically and mentally burned out. Former India batter and current National Cricket Academy (NCA) head VVS Laxman is in charge of the Indian team in New Zealand in Dravid‚Äôs absence. ‚ÄúI will explain why Laxman has gone there with a completely different team because even that could be interpreted differently,‚Äù Ashwin said on his YouTube channel. ‚ÄúRahul Dravid and his team put in extensive hard work ahead of the T20 World Cup ‚Äì right from planning. Since I saw this from close quarters, I‚Äôm saying this. ‚ÄúThey had specific in-depth plans for each venue and each opposition. So they would have been under not only mental but also physical burnout, and everyone needed a break. ‚ÄúAs soon as the New Zealand series ends, we have the Bangladesh tour. That‚Äôs why we have a different coaching staff led by Laxman for this tour.‚Äù Dravid, one of India‚Äôs greatest batters, was given a rest after the T20 World Cup as Laxman became India‚Äôs stand-in coach for the tour of New Zealand, with Hardik Pandya taking over as captain for the T20I series. The arrangement didn‚Äôt go down well with Shastri, who was replaced by Dravid at the end of the 2021 T20 World Cup in the UAE. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe in breaks. I want to understand my team and players, and then be in control of that team. What do you need that many breaks for, to be honest? You get your two-three months of the IPL, that‚Äôs enough for you to rest as a coach,‚Äù Shastri had said. ‚ÄúBut other times, I think a coach should be hands-on, whoever he is.‚Äù India qualified for the semi-finals of the T20 World Cup in Australia after winning four out of five group matches, but were humiliated by eventual champions England. Dravid had been also rested for a tour of Zimbabwe earlier this year. India‚Äôs ongoing tour of New Zealand comprises three T20Is and three ODIs. After that, India will be in Bangladesh for three ODIs and two Tests, and Dravid will be back for that tour. newsArray.title: Getting nasty: Which club is leaking to headquarters?
newsArray.description: NRL clubs are almost back to being normal.
newsArray.content: The feeling of solidarity in the funding dispute with the NRL is fast disappearing.Half the clubs now want to accept the NRL‚Äôs latest offer, the other half don‚Äôt.It‚Äôs getting nasty behind the scenes.One CEO, who shall remain nameless, has been accused of sharing sensitive information from chief executive phone hook-ups straight to NRL headquarters.This guy won‚Äôt have too many mates at the next CEO‚Äôs conference. That can be assured.If it‚Äôs true it‚Äôs a low act and even Super League-esque.The split in the ranks is just what the NRL wanted.The solid clubs want to look after their major asset ‚Äî the players ‚Äî and hold off on agreement until the RLPA deal for player wages is finalised.At least we know it‚Äôs back to business as usual. That the unity could never last.Not in rugby league. It‚Äôs the game that lives off bitter rivalries and hostilities. SAINT, SINNER, SHOOSH: LOW BLOW FOR GALLENIn a major snub, old warhorse Paul Gallen has been relegated from main event status for his farewell fight against Justin Hodges on Wednesday night.It is a huge shock and could be considered disrespectful to the 41-year-old sporting warrior who has regularly dragged in big pay-per-view audiences for promoters No Limit and Foxtel‚Äôs Main Event.In fairness Gallen‚Äôs form has been on the decline for two years and the fight with Hodges, whom he fought not so long ago, lacks the appeal of some of his bigger shows.Age has finally caught up with one of Australia‚Äôs toughest ever sports stars.Instead the highly regarded world middleweight contender Michael Zerafa has been given the main billing on Wednesday night at Darling Harbour‚Äôs International convention centre.It marks an incredible turnaround for Zerafa, who infamously pulled out of his much-hyped grudge match against Tim Tszyu in July last year.So low were the Melburnians‚Äô stocks at the time, there was even talk he would never fight on television in Australia again.But with a new team and talk of a potential world title shot against Gennady Golovkin on the horizon, Zerafa risks it all against Sydney-based Italian Danilo Creati.It will be a huge night of boxing with another rugby league star on debut as Gallen calls it a day.As first reported by this column, France bound ex-Rooster Siua Sio Taukehio has been confirmed to make his boxing debut against former South Sydney, Cowboys and Storm enforcer Jaiman Lowe.Securing the Tongan international a fight had been a challenge for promoters due the timing around the rugby league world Cup.South Sydney Rabbitohs forward Daniel Suluka-Fifita will also make his professional boxing debut on the card. Suluka-Fifita has been training under the watchful eye legendary trainer of Johnny Lewis for the past eight weeks having started boxing training at Redfern PCYC as a 13 year-old.* * * * * SAINTFooty legend Ian Walsh came from the tiny country town of Eugowra that has been wiped out in the floods. Walsh‚Äôs daughter Donna still lives in the area. Donna is assisting in the huge recovery operation and has appealed to NRL clubs to help out. Not with money but with manpower. ‚ÄúEugowra put dad on the map as a rugby league player,‚Äù Donna said, ‚ÄúI know he‚Äôd want me to be reaching out to the game when the town is suffering like it is.‚Äù Donna has even organised for Dominos to supply free pizzas for the clean-up operation. All she needs now is some players. Donna can be contacted on 0409 743 682 if you‚Äôd like to help out.SINNERWe all love Victor Radley, even those who dislike the Roosters. He‚Äôs a great character and a tough old-school footy player. However there comes a time when we all need to grow up and walk away from a looming incident and/or violence, even when provoked. It‚Äôs time for him to start behaving like a professional athlete.SHOOSHWhich big-name NRL star is talking to a rival Sydney club about the possibility of him quitting his team for an immediate switch. It is potentially a monster story.SPOTTEDCommission chairman Peter V‚Äôlandys and NRL boss Andrew Abdo entering the North Sydney headquarters of the independent always ‚Äì or at least sometimes ‚Äì Nine Entertainment, presumably for a meeting with CEO Mike Sneesby and senior SMH editorial executives last week.SPOTTEDIt can be tough work for a boxer preparing to fight for a world title. Tim Tszyu has moved his training camp to Thailand ahead of the January super fight against Jermell Charlo. He takes a break every now and then to go jetskiing.SPOTTEDThe great Ken Arthurson has understandably been struggling since the recent passing of his lovely wife, Barbara. It helps that there are good people like Tom Trbojevic around. Turbo picked up the phone last week to ring and check in on the legendary old Manly supremo. Their chat has given Arko an enormous lift.SPOTTEDAllianz Stadium maintenance staff replacing 30 seats that were stomped on and smashed by fans at the Sydney FC v Wanderers derby last weekend. Sydney FC will be getting the repair bill in the mail next week. SPOTTEDIt doesn‚Äôt always pay to have India or Pakistan in big cricket finals in Australia. This is an empty bar at the MCG last Sunday night in the 14th over of the game. Their fans rarely drink at the cricket. It costs the caterers big time. If the Aussies were playing, they‚Äôd be lining up six-deep. THE POLITICIAN, HONEY KING PRAWNS AND NOT-SO-SECRET MEETINGNo other NRL club can leak sensitive information like the Canterbury Bulldogs.You‚Äôll remember last November Eels hooker Reed Mahoney was having a private dinner in the club‚Äôs Chinese restaurant with Gus Gould and Trent Barrett. Contract talks over honey king prawns and Mongolian lamb. A picture was sent straight to The Daily Telegraph.You‚Äôve got to wonder why they met in such a public space.Then there was the photo of Billy Kikau in a Bulldogs shirt at Belmore with Gus and Baz being leaked last year while he was still at the Penrith Panthers. Highly embarrassing for Kikau, who copped a hard time from his fans.An employee, who took a frame from security CCTV and circulated it on social media, was sacked.Then July this year. Cameron Ciraldo and his manager George Mimis had a secret lunch with Bulldogs sponsor Craig Laundy to discuss the coaching job. Footage was leaked straight to Channel 9. This week, same again. Hotel billionaire Arthur Laundy signed up for a new five-year sponsorship deal to match the length of Ciraldo‚Äôs coaching contract.It‚Äôs worth $1 million a year or $1.2 million if they make the finals.A good positive story about a rock-solid businessman who signed up when the club was at its lowest but is now committing long term.The plan was to make a major announcement this week to ensure Laundy got maximum exposure.Turns out Craig Laundy had photos taken on his phone at the official signing. He shared them with Gould, Ciraldo and other mates on Wednesday night. His pictures then hit social media.To be fully transparent, your columnist is writing this with a certain amount of disappointment.We were going to reveal the $5 million sponsorship deal two weeks ago. Chairman John Khoury and CEO Aaron Warburton asked us to hold off. We made an agreement. We would break the story this week before their official announcement.Craig Laundy, a former Liberal federal minister, is like all politicians. They leak like a sieve.The Daily Telegraph NRL Podcast ‚Äì PlaylistBOO & BALI A TRIBUTE TO FIFITARecently retired Sharks big man Andrew Fifita has found himself in a little bit of froth and bubble while holidaying in Bali.But before you jump to conclusions, the froth and bubble was courtesy of a barista who amazed the 2016 premiership hero, garnishing his brew with a recent tribute cartoon, done by Telegraph sports sketcher Boo Bailey.The copying process is a specialty of the house at Coffee Cartel and had a surprised Fifita joking: ‚ÄúI got squeezed out of the Sharks cap, but made it into this one.‚ÄùSYDNEY FC SIGN UP 11-YEAR-OLD TWINSSydney FC have signed their youngest ever players ‚Äì 11-year-old identical twin brothers.Jacob and Benjamin Zaidel have joined the club‚Äôs junior academy alongside some of the country‚Äôs most outstanding soccer prospects.It is an exciting story on the eve of the World Cup that local clubs are now following the lead of global giants in Europe and South America by recognising kids at such a young age.‚ÄúThey live and breathe the game,‚Äù says their dad Dani. ‚ÄúWho knows what the future holds ‚Äì as long as they keep enjoying it.‚ÄùInterestingly there are rules in the NRL that prevent clubs from signing players before they turn 15.The boys have been identified by Kelly Cross, Sydney FC‚Äôs youth technical director, who has a long and proud history of nurturing the best talent in Australian soccer.Kelly is a former head of football at Westfield Sports High who coached current Socceroos Aaron Mooy and Andrew Redmayne, as well as Harry Kewell, Alex Brosque and Jason Culina.‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been monitoring Ben and Jacob for a period of time and it became clear that they were both equally talented,‚Äù Cross said.‚ÄúYou couldn‚Äôt tell them apart in terms of ability so it helped that they were wearing different coloured and numbered bibs so there were no problems identifying them.‚ÄúThey are only 11-years old but they are promising young players showing creative potential and it‚Äôs great to bring them into our environment.‚ÄúThey are great kids, bubbly and enthusiastic with a good attitude. They get on well with each other and their peers.‚ÄùThe boys‚Äô dad Dani could not be prouder.‚ÄúSydney FC start with Under 13‚Äôs at their academy,‚Äù he said, ‚ÄúThe boys are going in a year early. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a year by year agreement that the parents sign.‚ÄúThey‚Äôve had a big advantage as twins kicking a football around the backyard from when they were tiny. They just love the game and are really excited about it.‚Äù‚ÄòROCKY‚Äô A GREAT MAN AND INNOVATORJournalism lost an all-time legend with the passing of Roy ‚ÄúRocky‚Äù Miller, a former editor of this newspaper and the most tragic St George Illawarra Dragons fan. The great man was 77.I learnt more from Rocky‚Äôs weekly Sunday Telegraph editorial meetings than I have from anyone in 46 years. He was a fanatical news chaser and innovator.Back in the 1980s, before anyone kept or thought of rugby league statistics, he sent copy boys to every game to do tackle counts. They became hugely popular in Monday‚Äôs papers.Our staff would all cheer for the Dragons each weekend knowing a victory would mean he‚Äôd be in a good mood for Tuesday morning conference. It could be miserable otherwise.As an editor, he was one of the great mentors. He gave me my start as a sports editor. I remember him playing an instrumental role in broadcaster Ray Hadley‚Äôs career in his early days. Hadley had just started the Continuous Call team on 2UE. He was up against the high-profile Hollywood and Zorba, a duo that won every footy ratings survey.Zorba used to joke: ‚ÄúRay could rob a bank without a balaclava and get away with it because no one knows who he is.‚ÄùHadley then made an appointment to meet Rocky. He needed to lift his profile and asked Miller if he could write a weekly column in The Sunday Telegraph sports section ‚Äì Hadley‚Äôs Hard Hits. He did it for free. He would soon become one of the major voices in league and regularly win the ratings.What I admired most was Rocky‚Äôs loyalty. He‚Äôd stick solid no matter what. Three weeks before his death he sent me a text about Dragons legend Craig Young, one of his all-time favourite players who was under siege as chairman for his controversial support of Brett Finch in a court reference.‚ÄúLook after him,‚Äù Rocky wrote. ‚ÄúHe made a mistake trying to help a mate (Finch‚Äôs father). Does not deserve to be crucified.‚ÄùTypical Rocky. Always looking after his beloved club ‚Ä¶ and his mates right to the end.* Rocky‚Äôs funeral is on Tuesday at 11am at St Aloysius church in Cronulla.

newsArray.title: Income of Rs.3,730 crore.. BCCI is the powerhouse of cricket
creator: The News Glory
newsArray.description: It is a well-known fact that the Board of Cricket in India (BCCI) still generates more revenue than any other national cricket board. But the BCCI has once again proved that it is the undisputed powerhouse of world cricket. Highest earning cricket board revealed by BCCI data According to data published by Times Now, the [‚Ä¶]
newsArray.content: It is a well-known fact that the Board of Cricket in India (BCCI) still generates more revenue than any other national cricket board. But the BCCI has once again proved that it is the undisputed powerhouse of world cricket. Highest earning cricket board revealed by BCCI data According to data published by Times Now, the Board of Control for Cricket in India has generated a revenue of Rs 3,730 crore in 2021. In second place is Cricket Australia, the Australian cricket board. Its revenue is Rs 2,843 crore. However, BCCI‚Äôs income is 23% higher than that of Australia. England & Wales Cricket Board took the third place. It earned a revenue of Rs 2,135 crore. Pakistan Pakistan Cricket Board (PCB) is at the fourth position with revenue of Rs 811 crore. Bangladesh Cricket Board is at the fifth position. It generates a revenue of Rs 802 crore. South Africa is sixth in the list with Rs 485 crore and New Zealand Cricket Board is seventh with Rs 210 crore. West Indies Cricket Board (Rs 116 crores), Zimbabwe Cricket Board (Rs 113 crores), and Sri Lanka Cricket (Rs 100 crores) occupy the bottom three spots in this list. It is noteworthy that IPL success has helped BCCI to become the unshakable cricket board in the world.

newsArray.title: Cooch Behar: Aman hits ton for Hyderabad
creator: Telangana Today

Batting first, Hyderabad posted a decent total with the help [‚Ä¶]
newsArray.content: Home | Sport | Cooch Behar Aman Hits Ton For Hyderabad Cooch Behar: Aman hits ton for Hyderabad By Telangana Today Published: Published Date - 11:21 PM, Sat - 19 November 22 Hyderabad: Aman Rao slammed a 155-ball 111 while Murugan Abhishek scored 80 to guide Hyderabad to 275 all out in 73.3 overs against Maharashtra on the first day of the Group-B U-19 Cooch Behar Trophy held at the MCA Cricket Stadium, Gahunje, Maharashtra on Saturday. Batting first, Hyderabad posted a decent total with the help of Aman‚Äôs century and Abhishek‚Äôs half-century. Aman‚Äôs ton included 18 boundaries and two over it. He added 115 runs partnership with Aravelly Avanish (39) for the opening wicket. Also Read Hyderabad witnesses first taste of formula cars For Maharashtra, Yash Borkar and AR Nishad scalped three wickets each while Razaq Fallah snared two wickets. At stumps, Maharashtra were 31/1 in 14 overs. Brief Scores: Hyderabad 275 in 73.3 overs (Aman Rao 111, Murugan Abhishek 80, Aravelly Avanish 39; Razaq Fallah 2/31, Yash Borkar 3/71, A R Nishad 3/43) vs Maharashtra 31/1 in 14 Overs (Arshin Kulkarni 21 batting); HCA U-16 Inter Schools, Colleges & Districts One Day Knock Out Tournament: Sri Chaitanya School (East Marredpally) 274 in 44.3 Overs (C Siddharth Rao 51, T Shiva Rama 78, M Ram Charan 48, B Srujan 3/38, CH Vinay 4/43) bt Adilabad 269/9 in 45 Overs (Simhadri 168; T Shiva Rama Krishna 4/22). newsArray.title: England implode to hand second ODI, series to Australia
creator: kuwaittimes
newsArray.description: SYDNEY: Australia wrapped up the three-match one-day international series with a comprehensive 72-run win over England at the Sydney Cricket Ground on Saturday. Chasing 281 to level the series after Australia won the first match in Adelaide on Thursday, England appeared well on track as Sam Billings and James Vince shared a 122-run partnership for ‚Ä¶ The post England implode to hand second ODI, series to Australia appeared first on Kuwait Times.
newsArray.content: Australia wrapped up the three-match one-day international series with a comprehensive 72-run win over England at the Sydney Cricket Ground on Saturday. Chasing 281 to level the series after Australia won the first match in Adelaide on Thursday, England appeared well on track as Sam Billings and James Vince shared a 122-run partnership for the fourth wicket. But once Vince was trapped lbw by stand-in Australian captain Josh Hazlewood for 60, the English imploded, losing 4-13 to virtually hand the Australians the match. On a tricky wicket at the SCG, Steve Smith continued the form he showed in Australia‚Äôs six-wicket win in Adelaide with a hard-fought 94 to help Australia to 280-8. The target always looked difficult on a surface that was playing slow with the occasional bad bounce. ‚ÄúIt looks easy to bat on when a partnership is going,‚Äù Hazlewood said of the surface. ‚ÄúBut you‚Äôre only a wicket away from causing a collapse on such a pitch. I was very happy with 280.‚Äù England got the worst possible start to the run chase when Jason Roy tickled Mitchell Starc‚Äôs second delivery down the leg side to keeper Alex Carey. Three balls later Starc got the key wicket of Dawid Malan with an almost unplayable ball that pitched on leg stump then swung back to take the top of off, leaving England staggering at two wickets for no runs. Phil Salt and Vince kept playing with the aggression that the England white-ball teams are renowned for, and took the score to 34 after five overs. But Salt tried one big shot too many, stepping away to try and smash Hazlewood over cover only to miss the ball and see it cannon into his stumps. Any hopes Australia may have had of crashing through the England batting lineup were dashed by Vince and Billings. The two mixed caution with aggression as they took the score to 156 before Vince was trapped by Hazlewood as he tried to hoist the Australian skipper over the square leg boundary. England captain Moeen Ali came in and smashed leg spinner Adam Zampa for a four and a six, then missed a top spinner and was bowled. At 168-5 after 28.3 overs, Australia were back in control and they tightened their grip one run later when Zampa bowled Billings for 71. England wickets kept tumbling as Starc (4-47), Hazlewood (2-33) and Zampa (4-45) wrapped up the English tail. ‚ÄúWe were in a good position with the bat but we lost wickets,‚Äù Ali said. ‚ÄúThe wicket actually got easier to bat on but we lost wickets-it‚Äôs just one of those things. ‚ÄúThey bowled well in that phase and the pressure got to us. If you lose wickets regularly, you‚Äôre not going to win many games.‚Äù Earlier, Smith‚Äôs 94 from 114 balls anchored the Australian innings after Hazlewood won the toss and decided to bat. Hazlewood was brought into the side for captain Pat Cummins, who was rested with an eye to the upcoming Test series against the West Indies. The pitch initially offered little help for the seamers but it deteriorated as the innings progressed. ‚Äì AFP

newsArray.title: Little by little perishing May Islands team: Kathikutty players who flipped!
creator: The News Glory
newsArray.description: The West Indies team, which has gone to Australia for the 2-Test series, drew a match against New South Wales and Act XI in a 3-day warm-up match. The fact that the two Kathucuti players of the team turned the bowling of the May Islands team is the talk of the Australian cricket world. May [‚Ä¶]
newsArray.content: The West Indies team, which has gone to Australia for the 2-Test series, drew a match against New South Wales and Act XI in a 3-day warm-up match. The fact that the two Kathucuti players of the team turned the bowling of the May Islands team is the talk of the Australian cricket world. May Islands play 2 Test matches in December. The 1st Test will be played in Perth and the 2nd Test will be played in Adelaide. In the 3-day practice match held in Canberra, May Islands batted first and scored 424 runs for the loss of 9 wickets. New South Wales and the Oct-11 team, who continued to bowl, turned the bowling over and declared (!) 426/4 in 97 overs. In the 2nd innings, May Isles stumbled to 114/4 and the game was drawn. In this, the misery of the May Islands team is that the 24-year-old player named Blake Macdonald, the captain of the New South Wales and Act XI team, scored 177 runs off 265 balls with 15 fours and 5 sixes. Another player, Oliver Davies, only 22, scored 115 runs off 106 balls with 14 fours and 3 sixes, while Justin Aventano scored 54 runs. The fact that these 3 players are Kathucutti players who have not yet played first-class cricket is being talked about in Australia as the main point that indicates the weakness of the May Islands bowling. If non-first-class players like Kimar Roach, Jayden Seals, Aljarri Joseph and off-spinner Ruston Chase are turning the ball around, what will a batting line-up of Warner, Khawaja, Travis Head, Smith and Labuschenne do for the May Islands in Test cricket against Australia? The talk has arisen in Australia. The fact that the May Islands team, which had already failed to qualify for the T20 World Cup, was invited for the Test series is seen by the Australian media as a mockery and sarcasm. Kimar Roche scored 34 runs against this Kathucutti team and failed to lose a single wicket in 13 overs. Jayden Seals, the current leading fast bowler for the May Islands, bowled 14 overs and failed to take a wicket. Aljari Joseph scored 54 runs in 13 overs, while Raston Chase scored 117 runs in 23 overs and took only one wicket. If the leading bowlers of the May Islands do not take wickets, how can they take wickets against Australia? Australian batsmen are expected to break many records in this series. It really adds to the sadness and pain that the bowling of the Isles of May has degraded to what it is today. In the end, the current top bowlers of the May Islands, even Kathucutti batsmen could beat them or they could not even beat players who had not even played first-class cricket. This state of affairs suggests that the greatest art of the May Islands, cricket, has reached its final days. Just like India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Bangladesh, cricket in the May Islands was developed by British colonialism as a great anti-colonial art and sport. It is hard to digest that today the art of cricket in the May Islands is slowly going downhill and dying unnoticed by the moneyed cricket world.

newsArray.title: What Surya does, I can‚Äôt even dream of doing: Glenn Phillips
creator: Post News Network
newsArray.description: Mount Maunganui: He is a T20 ace in his own right but New Zealander Glenn Phillips says he can‚Äôt even ‚Äúdream‚Äù of pulling off some of the incredible shots that Suryakumar Yadav plays with ease. Surya, world No. 1 T20 batter, will square off against Phillips‚Äô New Zealand in the second game here at the [‚Ä¶]
newsArray.content: What Surya does, I can‚Äôt even dream of doing: Glenn Phillips PTI Updated: November 19th, 2022, 21:35 IST in Sports 0 Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share on WhatsApp Share on Linkedin Mount Maunganui: He is a T20 ace in his own right but New Zealander Glenn Phillips says he can‚Äôt even ‚Äúdream‚Äù of pulling off some of the incredible shots that Suryakumar Yadav plays with ease. Surya, world No. 1 T20 batter, will square off against Phillips‚Äô New Zealand in the second game here at the Bay Oval, a ground where the Black caps dasher has fond memories of scoring a 46-ball hundred. ‚ÄúHe (Surya) is absolutely incredible. The things that he does I wouldn‚Äôt even dream of doing. I would love to try but we have very different games. The wrist strength that he‚Äôs got to be able to hit balls for six in extremely awkward areas is a talent you rarely see,‚Äù Phillips was quoted as saying in stuff.Co.Nz. Phillips also mentioned that the ‚Äúhigh risk-high reward game‚Äù that is played by him and Surya also keeps opposition in the game as they have the danger of getting out if some of those adventurous shots aren‚Äôt executed properly. ‚ÄúI have got my strengths and he has got his and we go about our jobs in different ways. And the way we both play presents opportunities for the opposition to get us out as well. It‚Äôs part of the risk and reward of middle order cricket in T20.‚Äù Surya has been world‚Äôs top run-getter in the 2022 calendar year with whopping 1040 runs at an average of 43 and a magnificent strike-rate of 186. Phillips is eighth in the ICC‚Äôs T20I batters‚Äô list and has scored 650 runs at a strike-rate of 158 plus. Phillips is fearing that on good batting tracks like Bay Oval (Mt Maunganui) and McLean Park (Napier), Surya‚Äôs strike-rate would soar even higher. ‚ÄúI could easily see (Surya‚Äôs) strike rate being even higher here than it was in Aussie, with the slightly smaller grounds and the pitches very similar, potentially a bit bouncier with a bit more grass on them. It‚Äôs going to be very interesting what sort of strike rates we see here.‚Äù PTI Tags: Glenn Phillips suryakumar yadav Share Tweet Send Share Suggest A Correction Enter your email to get our daily news in your inbox. newsArray.title: England‚Äôs World Cup hangover worsens as they lose series to Australia with 72-run defeat in second ODI in Sydney
creator: John Etheridge
newsArray.content: ENGLAND slumped to another defeat as their World Cup hangover continued with a 50-over series defeat against Australia. Hampshire‚Äôs James Vince and Kent‚Äôs Sam Billings gave England hope of overhauling the Aussies‚Äô total of 280-8 in Sydney. 4 David Willey showed his frustrations after being dismissed in the defeat Credit: AFP 4 Adam Zampa was a thorn in the side of Matthew Motts' troops Credit: EPA 4 Australia celebrate their victory over a lacklustre England Credit: GETTY The pair put on 122 for the fourth wicket after a terrible start by England that included losing both Jason Roy and Dawid Malan to Mitchell Starc in the opening over of the reply. But, once Vince was lbw to stand-in Aussie skipper Josh Hazlewood for 60, England‚Äôs innings fell apart and they lost their last seven wickets for just 52 runs. Billings made 71 but England‚Äôs next-highest score was 23 by opener Phil Salt. Billings said: ‚ÄúThose early wickets really pegged us back and we had to rebuild. "The pitch was quite tricky ‚Äì a bit two-paced ‚Äì and Australia‚Äôs score was probably above par. ‚ÄúIt was a real shame Vincey and I couldn't go on for at least another ten overs. "I‚Äôve had to be patient and I didn‚Äôt have many opportunities with the white ball for England last summer. I think I‚Äôve averaged over 50 in the last three years in ODI cricket. ‚ÄúMore than half the group have been here for a long time ‚Äì they must try to muster energy for the last game. Most read in Cricket SHANE SHOCK Shane Warne fan climbs in ambulance with body as cops probe ‚Äòsecurity breach‚Äô TWEET ROW England women star Hartley leaves Root's team furious with joke about India loss RIP MAESTRO Legendary Pakistan cricketer Qadir dead at 63 after cardiac arrest 'She will be missed' Ex-England women's cricket captain and Wolves vice-president Rachael Heyhoe-Flint dies aged 77 PLAY OUR DREAM TEAM WORLD CUP FANTASY FOOTBALL GAME TO WIN A SHARE OF ¬£50k "For the five of us who came into the squad a week ago, it‚Äôs a huge opportunity to stake a claim and be the energy for the rest.‚Äù After a loss to India and draw with South Africa at home in the summer, England have now failed to win three consecutive one-day series for the first time since 2015. They have won the Twenty20 World Cup, of course, and it appears they are still struggling to lift themselves after that triumph. The third and now dead-rubber match is in Melbourne on Tuesday. Captain Jos Buttler rested himself with Moeen Ali captaining England for the first time in a one-dayer. 4 Steve Smith racked up a half-century for Australia Credit: EPA Chris Woakes, Adil Rashid and Sam Curran also returned as England made four changes from the team that lost the first match in Adelaide on Thursday. The Aussies also had a change of captain with Pat Cummins having a breather and Hazlewood taking charge. It shows that neither side is approaching this team with 100 per cent determination to win at all costs. Australia‚Äôs innings featured half-centuries for Steve Smith ‚Äì who was caught on the boundary for 94 attempting to reach his hundred with a six ‚Äì along with Marnus Labuschagne and Mitch Marsh. Rashid took three wickets while Woakes and David Willey had two apiece. Read More on The Sun 's***show' Fans all say same thing about awful World Cup fan zone food including ¬£9 salad ATTENTION GRABBER I‚Äôm a teacher ‚Äì I go from a 5 to a 10 when I strip off my work outfit In reply, Roy‚Äôs shocking form continued when he was caught down the legside for a duck and Malan, who made a century in the first match, also perished without scoring courtesy of a swinging ripper from Starc. Salt backed away, aimed a horrible hack and was bowled. Vince and Billings repaired the damage but, once they departed, the end came quickly with 11.1 overs of England‚Äôs innings unbowled.

newsArray.title: Hazlewood proves captaincy chops on debut
creator: wwos
newsArray.description: JÔªøosh Hazlewood showed he has what it takes to be a regular captain, making a series of crucial bowling changes at the perfect time.
newsArray.content: Josh Hazlewood has proved his captaincy chops in his first match leading Australia, with a series of crucial bowling changes resulting in a win in the second ODI.Australia set England an imposing target of 280 after batting first at the SCG, courtesy of a brilliant 94 from Steve Smith, and looked on course for a huge win when Mitchell Starc (4-47 off eight overs) removed both Jason Roy and Dawid Malan in the first over.However, England was buoyed by a wonderful 122-run stand between James Vince (60) and Sam Billings (71) that had the tourists briefly daring to dream of an improbable victory. AS IT HAPPENED: Zampa, Starc help Australia to series winÔªøREAD MORE: The season that nearly broke four-time F1 champÔªøÔªøREAD MORE: 'Disgraceful' Beckham's icon status 'shredded'On a wicket that had proved tricky to bat on for batters from both sides, Vince and Billings were motoring along when Hazlewood decided to bring himself on in the 28th over. The decision proved to be crucial, with Australia's stand-in skipper removing Vince in his first over back into the attack. If Vince's wicket got Australia's foot in the door, Adam Zampa (4-45 off nine) wrenched it wide open, effectively sealing the win by taking three wickets in the space of nine deliveries to gut England's middle order.Speaking after the match, Hazlewood explained how he'd been so preoccupied with the duties of captaining that he'd almost forgotten to bring himself into the attack."ÔªøI was looking around and thinking who's next to bowl and then I thought I'd better have a go," he said."It's good fun having the captaincy. I'll obviously hand it over to Pat again for the last game, but yeah, I thoroughly enjoyed it and the boys certainly helped me out from time to time."After Vince and Billings' stand had seen England reach 3-156 at one stage, it lost its last seven wickets for just 52 runs to be all out for 208.ÔªøStarc returned to the attack to clean up the tail following Hazlewood and Zampa's spree of wickets, and was named the Player of the Match for his efforts.The 72-run win gives Australia an unassailable 2-0 lead in the three-match series, with the series finale to be played at the Melbourne Cricket Ground on Tueday.For a daily dose of the best of the breaking news and exclusive content from Wide World of Sports, subscribe to our newsletter by clicking here!

newsArray.description: India vs New Zealand: Men in Blue receive traditional welcome at Mt. Maunganui ahead of second T20I
newsArray.content: Cricket India vs New Zealand: Men in Blue receive traditional welcome at Mt. Maunganui ahead of second T20I Captain of the side Hardik Pandya also marked his presence in some of the traditional activities FP Trending November 19th, 2022 16:51:02 IST India received a traditional Maori welcome upon arrival for the second T20I. Image: BCCI/Twitter After the first T20I of their New Zealand tour was abandoned due to rain, Indian team arrived for the second contest at the Bay Oval on Sunday. Following their visit to Mount Maunganui, the cricketers received a warm traditional welcome from the Maori community. The community staged a traditional ceremony to greet the entire Indian team and support staff. Through a variety of events, Maori individuals showcased their rich culture. The Hardik Pandya-led team seemingly enjoyed the activity. Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) posted pictures from the beautiful ceremony. üì∏ üì∏ Snapshots from #TeamIndia ‚Äòs traditional welcome at Mt. Maunganui Image Courtesy: Jamie Troughton/Dscribe Media #NZvIND pic.twitter.com/K4yUiScPO7 ‚Äî BCCI (@BCCI) November 19, 2022 The Maori are the native inhabitants of New Zealand, who migrated to the country in huge numbers of canoes between 1250 and 1300. Speeches, dancing and singing are typical elements of a Maori greeting ceremony or powhiri. During the ceremony, India‚Äôs interim head coach VVS Laxman accompanied the players and enjoyed the rituals with them. Some Maori people showed off their sword skills in front of the squad. In the pictures, Indian bowlers like Harshal Patel, Mohammed Siraj and Yuzvendra Chahal can be spotted watching the event from the front row. Captain Pandya also marked his presence in some of the activities. The caption of BCCI‚Äôs post reads, ‚ÄúSnapshots from Team India‚Äôs traditional welcome at Mt. Maunganui.‚Äù Fans applauded the efforts of the New Zealand cricket board for organising such an exciting event. A user appreciated, ‚ÄúGreat welcome, Black Caps.‚Äù Great Wellcome @BLACKCAPS ‚ù§Ô∏èüáÆüá≥üôè ‚Äî ü¶è G√∏√ªr√¢v Soni/ ‡§ó‡•å‡§∞‡§µ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§®‡•Ä (@Gouravs15193715) November 19, 2022 Another person noted, ‚ÄúHardik and his army.‚Äù HARDIK AND HIS ARMY!!!! ‚Äî Rohirat (@CRohitkrishna) November 19, 2022 A fan wished, ‚ÄúAll the best, Hardik.‚Äù All the best hardik.. ‚Äî Hans Suryawanshi (@SuryawanshiHans) November 19, 2022 However, this is not the first time that the Maori community has welcomed the Men in Blue. Back in 2019, the Virat Kohli-led ODI side received the same kind of treatment when they came to Mount Maunganui to play the second ODI of the five-match series. newsArray.title: Manika Batra wins bronze medal at Asian Cup, creates history for India
creator: FP Sports
newsArray.description: Manika Batra wins bronze medal at Asian Cup, creates history for India
newsArray.content: Sports Manika Batra wins bronze medal at Asian Cup, creates history for India Manika Batra defeated Hina Hayata 11-6, 6-11, 11-7, 12-10, 4-11, 11-2 to clinch the bronze medal at the Asian Cup FP Sports November 19, 2022 15:07:08 IST Manika Batra defeated Hina Hayata 11-6, 6-11, 11-7, 12-10, 4-11, 11-2. Image: YouTube screenshots Manika Batra created history on Saturday after she became the first Indian woman to win a medal at the Asian Cup. Batra defeated Hina Hayata 11-6, 6-11, 11-7, 12-10, 4-11, 11-2 to clinch the bronze medal in the competition. She had earlier lost to fourth seed Mima Ito of Japan 8-11 11-7 7-11 6-11 11-8 7-11 (2-4) in the semi-final. Despite the semis loss, the Indian paddler ensured the best finish by an Indian in the 39-year-old history of the competition. Achanta Sharath Kamal and G Sathiyan had finished sixth in 2015 and 2019 respectively. newsArray.title: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt fit the eligibility criteria‚Äù: Parthiv Patel confirms he can‚Äôt apply for Indian national cricket team selector post due to eligibility concerns
creator: Rishikesh Sharma
newsArray.description: After the disappointing T20 World Cup 2022, it was expected that some major changes will be done in the management as well, and BCCI sacked all the national selectors to start the process. BCCI have already started inviting applications for the same, and Parthiv Patel has confirmed that he does not fit the criteria. The‚Ä¶ The post ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt fit the eligibility criteria‚Äù: Parthiv Patel confirms he can‚Äôt apply for Indian national cricket team selector post due to eligibility concerns appeared first on The SportsRush.
newsArray.content: After the disappointing T20 World Cup 2022, it was expected that some major changes will be done in the management as well, and BCCI sacked all the national selectors to start the process. BCCI have already started inviting applications for the same, and Parthiv Patel has confirmed that he does not fit the criteria. The selection committee consisted of Chetan Sharma (North Zone), Harvinder Singh (Central Zone), Sunil Joshi (South Zone) and Debasish Mohanty (East Zone). This is one of the shortest spells for any selection committee, and they have been criticized for the lack of stability on the side and for not selecting a stable team for the tournaments. The defeat in the Asia Cup and T20 World Cup, along with the rushing of Jasprit Bumrah to international cricket are seen as the main reasons behind the sacking. Interestingly, the new selectors have been assigned the role of selecting a new captain for different formats as well. Parthiv Patel confirms he can‚Äôt apply for Indian national cricket team selector post Former Indian wicket-keeper Parthiv Patel has confirmed that he will not apply for the role of national selector as he does not fit the eligibility criteria. A fan asked Parthiv to apply for the role, but he clarified that he will not be applying this time, but it will be an honour for him if he gets the opportunity in the future. ‚ÄúThank you but I don‚Äôt fit the eligibility criteria for the post at the moment. It would be an honour to be offered the position in the future,‚Äù Parthiv Patel tweeted. Thank you but I don‚Äôt fit the eligibility criteria for the post at the moment. It would be an honour to be offered the position in the future. https://t.co/Tonv39wgsj ‚Äî parthiv patel (@parthiv9) November 19, 2022 BCCI have already started inviting applications for the role of new national selectors, and they have set some eligibility criteria for the same that are mentioned below. 1) Should have played a minimum of 7 test matches or 30 FC Matches or 10 ODI and 20 FC Matches. 2) Should have retired from the game at least 5 years ago. 3) No person who has been a member of any cricket committee for a total of 5 years. The post ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt fit the eligibility criteria‚Äù: Parthiv Patel confirms he can‚Äôt apply for Indian national cricket team selector post due to eligibility concerns appeared first on The SportsRush.

newsArray.title: 2nd T20I: India face Bhuvneshwar dilemma while praying for game time
newsArray.description: Mount Maunganui, November 19Bhuvneshwar Kumar faces an arduous challenge of remaining relevant in shortest format as a young Indian team, seeking some game time, is expected to face tough resistance from New Zealand in the second T20 International here on Sunday.The series-opener in Wellington was abandoned due to inclement weather and the Indian players must be itching to get onto the park which, inarguably, has the most scenic backdrop.Ironically, the region where the ground is located is known as 'Bay of Plenty' and Indian cricket at this point has plenty to ponder as far as its approach in T20 format is concerned.While the Sky Stadium was shorter in terms of dimensions, the Indian team will have to make adjustments as the 'Bay Oval' ground has bigger side boundaries and is an open ground unlike Wellington.The Bhuvi conundrumOn this tour, the presence of a near 33 year-old Bhuvneshwar is one such dilemma that the team management might have to handle. There are some probing questions and quicker the answers are sought, better it would be for Indian cricket.Is Bhuvneshwar going to be around for the T20 World Cup in 2024 with a sharp decline in his pace? Does he have enough time to work around his issues as he is not potent enough on good batting tracks? Not many T20Is are lined-up next year and he is largely becoming a single-format player, so where does it leave him?At this moment, all the answers seem to be in negative and hence a question arises whether playing the senior-most pacer would be akin to taking away an opportunity from a youngster to get into the groove.It is a double-edged sword that interim head coach VVS Laxman and captain Pandya will be facing.Not playing Bhuvneshwar when he is on the cusp of a personal milestone (4 more wickets for highest tally of 40 in a calendar year) might leave him demoralised.Most of his 36 wickets have come in bowler-friendly conditions and against lesser opponents. On slightly flatter wickets and against better batting attacks, Bhuvneshwar has come a cropper.But playing him will be a missed opportunity for the team management to check out on how the pair of Umran Malik and Mohammed Siraj would match up against the might of players like Finn Allen, Glenn Phillips and Devon Conway in pressure situations.Umran, India's fastest bowler by a distance, needs to be groomed. Pakistan has shown with Haris Rauf, Shaheen Shah Afridi and Naseem Shah as to what extreme pace can do.Ishan or Shubman, the choice of opener?The moment Rishabh Pant was named the vice-captain of the team for the T20I series, it was a given that he would be opening but whether Shubman Gill with his new found confidence in this format or the specialist Ishan Kishan will pair up is there to be seen.In case of Kishan, who has had troubles against genuine pace and swing is preferred, then there will be two left-handers at the top while Gill's presence will make it a left-right combination.The other factor would be the choice between KKR skipper Shreyas Iyer, not exactly a fast starter in T20Is and the dynamic Deepak Hooda, who can also bowl wicket-to-wicket tight off-breaks.To accommodate both Hooda and Shreyas, Kishan will then needed to be dropped from the playing XI. Sanju Samson and skipper Pandya are the two batters along with Suryakumar Yadav, who would play the role of enforcers as well as finishers.Chahal vs Phillips match-upGlenn Phillips, one of the most exciting T20 batters in recent times, will have a battle in hand when the wily Yuzvendra Chahal gets his first game in many moons after being inexplicably benched by regular head coach Rahul Dravid throughout the T20 World Cup.But the last completed T20I match at this ground witnessed Phillips score 108 off 51 balls with as many as eight sixes against a quality West Indies attack.With Ravichandran Ashwin's T20I career all but over, Washington Sundar will be getting a long run as a specialist off-spinner while Harshal Patel will also get game time to get back his rhythm which deserted him just before the World Cup. Arshdeep Singh as a left-arm seamer looks a sure-shot starter in next two games.Squads:India: Hardik Pandya (captain), Rishabh Pant (vc and wk), Shubman Gill, Suryakumar Yadav, Sanju Samson, Shreyas Iyer, Ishan Kishan (wk), Deepak Hooda, Yuzvendra Chahal, Kuldeep Yadav, Washington Sundar, Harshal Patel, Bhuvneshwar Kumar, Umran Malik, Mohammed Siraj, Arshdeep Singh New Zealand: Kane Williamson (captain), Devon Conway, Finn Allen, Glenn Phillips, Devon Cinway, Daryl Mitchell, Adam Milne, Michael Bracewll, Ish Sodhi, Mitchell Santner, Lockie Ferguson, Tim Southee, Blair Tickner.Match Starts: 12 noon IST.

newsArray.title: Cricket legend calls out Aussie dugout sight
newsArray.description: Australian cricket great Ian Healy has questioned George Bailey‚Äôs influence within the team, after the chairman of selectors was spotted sitting with players in the dugout.
newsArray.content: Bailey, a former Aussie T20 captain who recently retired in 2020, was appointed the new selection chief in August 2021, taking over from Trevor Hohns‚Äô lengthy stint.Watch Australia v England. Every ODI live and ad-break free in play on Kayo. New to Kayo? Start your free trial now >But former captain Ian Healy has questioned why someone like Bailey would be sitting among the players throughout the dismal T20 World Cup campaign and in Thursday night‚Äôs one dayer against England.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very interesting,‚Äù Healy said on his SEN show.‚ÄúGeorge Bailey can throw well, he can provide an extra coach around the traps ‚Ä¶ but he‚Äôs not an extra coach is he? He‚Äôs a selector.‚ÄúI think in-form players wouldn‚Äôt mind (having him next to them); I think down on form players would hate it and have to start acting.‚ÄúI think injured-type players carrying niggles small or maybe a little bit larger wouldn‚Äôt be keen to have the chairman of selectors so close.‚ÄúThe reserves in that dug out, are they acting?‚ÄúIf the acting isn‚Äôt good ‚Ä¶ they could be exposed. ‚ÄúThe current mood in that team might change ‚Ä¶ that might be creating stress with the selector so upfront and so close.‚ÄùHealy said given there were controversial calls made during the T20 World Cup campaign, where Australia missed out on the finals, he wasn‚Äôt sure how players would feel with Bailey sitting beside them.‚ÄúWe swapped (Mitchell) Starc for (Kane) Richardson at a time when we were after wickets. We kept Steve Smith out (of the T20 World Cup),‚Äù he said.‚ÄúWe let out of form players stay in that team in that T20 World Cup and that‚Äôs all while the chairman of selectors was in the dug out and very, very close to the personality of the squad.‚ÄúIf he asks you a question (players would go), ‚ÄòAll right, what have I got to tell him?‚ÄôBailey was filmed having a laugh with star duo Warner and Marnus Labuschagne during Thursday night‚Äôs game one victory over England.Fellow SEN panellist, and current Brisbane Lions captain, Dayne Zorko compared Bailey‚Äôs presence in the dug out to having his list manager on the interchange bench.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very strange ‚Äì especially if you‚Äôre a person on the fringe or not really getting a game,‚Äù he said on SEN.‚ÄúIt would be like our list manager sitting on the bench when I come off and I haven‚Äôt had a good patch. He‚Äôs just looking at me (and I say) ‚ÄòOh I can do better!‚Äô.‚ÄùThe Australian cricket team is reportedly struggling with an ‚Äúapparent divide‚Äù between current players and the nation‚Äôs greats.It was reported captain Pat Cummins has met with Adam Gilchrist this week to ‚Äúcool any potential tensions‚Äù since ex-coach Justin Langer was pushed out the door in February.
